title: Social Media Was a C.E.O.’s Bullhorn, and How He Lured Women
abstract: Dan Price was applauded for paying a minimum salary of $70,000 at his Seattle company and criticizing corporate greed. The adulation helped to hide and enable his behavior.

multimedia.caption:
“Lifting someone out of poverty is the most effective anti-depressant in the world.”
 — @DanPriceSeattle

title: TikTok Browser Can Track Users’ Keystrokes, According to New Research
abstract: In the web browser used within the TikTok app, supplementary code lets the company track every character typed by users. The company said the capability was for troubleshooting.
byline: By Paul Mozur, Ryan Mac and Chang Che

multimedia.caption: TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.
TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.
TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.

title: Can Tesla Data Help Us Understand Car Crashes?
abstract: Data and video recorded by Tesla and other automakers to hone driver-assistance systems can also be an investigative tool for regulators and lawyers.
byline: By Cade Metz and Ella Koeze

title: Facebook and Instagram Remove Robert Kennedy Jr.’s Nonprofit for Misinformation
abstract: The social networking company said that Children’s Health Defense, a group led by Mr. Kennedy, an anti-vaccine activist, had “repeatedly” violated its guidelines by spreading medical misinformation.

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. during a protest in Washington against vaccine and mask mandates in January.

title: A Teen’s Journey Into the Internet’s Darkness and Back Again
abstract: As anxiety and depression soar among adolescents, researchers struggle to understand how exactly social media affects mental health.
byline: By Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan

multimedia.caption: “I feel like if I was born in 2000 B.C. in the Alps, I’d still be depressive, but I think it’s wildly exacerbated by the climate we live in,” said C, who is 22 and lives in Salt Lake City.

title: Expansion of Clean Energy Loans Is ‘Sleeping Giant’ of Climate Bill
abstract: The bill President Biden signed into law recently will greatly expand government loans and loan guarantees for clean energy and automotive projects and businesses.

title: More Than ‘Weird’: Roku Embraces Original Programming
abstract: The streaming media device company wants to attract more viewers and advertisers to its channel. A coming biopic of “Weird Al” Yankovic is its most ambitious project to date.

multimedia.caption: Quinta Brunson as Oprah Winfrey and Daniel Radcliffe as “Weird Al” Yankovic in “Weird,” which will be available on Roku in November.

title: A Dad Took Photos of His Naked Toddler for the Doctor. Google Flagged Him as a Criminal.
abstract: Google has an automated tool to detect abusive images of children. But the system can get it wrong, and the consequences are serious.

title: The Fried Chicken Inflation Index
abstract: YouTube star Elijah Quashie, of the U.K. hit “The Pengest Munch,” copes with the rising cost of wings.

title: How the Find My App Became an Accidental Friendship Fixture
abstract: Introduced 10 years ago, the app has slowly become a popular way to keep track of friends. But it comes with considerable privacy concerns.

title: Twitter Tells Employees They Might Get Only Half Their Annual Bonus
abstract: The company blamed its financial performance for the potential bonus cut.
byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

multimedia.caption: Twitter, which is in the middle of a legal battle with Elon Musk, reported a decline in revenue for the first time since 2020 in its earnings report last month.

title: Lawmakers Demand Social Media Firms Address Threats to Law Enforcement
abstract: The Democrats who lead two House panels also expressed concern about “reckless statements” from Republicans after a surge in online threats following the F.B.I. search of Mar-a-Lago.
org_facet: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

title: She Had an AirTag in Her Lost Luggage. It Led Police to a Baggage Handler’s Home.
abstract: An airport worker in Florida was charged with two counts of grand theft after a tracking device aided a sheriff’s investigation.

title: The Faded but Winning Pandemic Star
abstract: Sales are down, but there is no need to pity the Chromebook.

title: Finland’s Prime Minister Parties, but Then Videos Leak
abstract: Criticism of the leader, Sanna Marin, 36, over parties she’s attended showed the difficulties of keeping life private in the age of cellphones and social media.

title: They Lost Crypto in the Crash. They’re Trying to Get It Back.
abstract: In a frenzied effort, investors are trying to recover lost funds from Celsius Network, a crypto firm that imploded this summer.

multimedia.caption: Alex Mashinsky, the founder of Celsius Network, a crypto bank that has filed for bankruptcy. Customers are now trying to recoup their lost funds.

title: Why Buying an Electric Car Just Became More Complicated
abstract: The new climate, tax and health law signed by President Biden extends a credit for electric vehicle buyers. But there are new strings attached that kick in at different times.
des_facet: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

multimedia.caption: The Inflation Reduction Act includes an extension of a tax credit for electric vehicles that is worth up to $7,500 per qualifying car or truck.

title: Wasn’t TikTok Supposed to Be Fun?
abstract: No social app remains free of arguments over politics and social issues once it becomes popular.

title: Wastewater Disease Tracking: A Photographic Journey From the Sewer to the Lab
abstract: Here’s how a scrappy team of scientists, public health experts and plumbers is embracing wastewater surveillance as the future of disease tracking.
byline: By Aliza Aufrichtig, Emily Anthes and Jonah Markowitz
org_facet: Queens College, City University of New York

title: At Last, Online Travel Planning Is Becoming (a Little) Easier
abstract: Airbnb, Google Travel and a few other platforms have tweaked their search engines, and that means less slogging through pages and pages of results on everything from home rental options to flight routes.

title: Tech Hacks to Make Traveling Right Now Less of a Headache
abstract: The travel industry is recovering from the pandemic, but messily. These apps and tips can help us navigate the chaos and maximize our comfort.

title: The Quantify-Everything Economy
abstract: Data can make our lives richer, but let’s not forget that people are not machines.

title: A Timeline of Trump’s False and Misleading Statements on the Mar-a-Lago Search
abstract: The former president has pushed frenetic and sometimes contradictory claims about the F.B.I.’s search of his Florida home.

title: Lyft Unveils Self-Driving Car Service in Las Vegas (With Caveats)
abstract: The company joins several others that are introducing self-driving services — but the cars often have drivers or are otherwise limited in their autonomy.

multimedia.caption: Two so-called safety drivers will ride along in each of Lyft’s new driverless cars in Las Vegas. It could be decades before truly autonomous vehicles are commonplace.

title: A Frustrating Hassle Holding Electric Cars Back: Broken Chargers
abstract: Owners of battery-powered cars sometimes struggle to refuel on longer trips because public chargers don’t work or malfunction while cars are plugged in.

title: The Rise of the Worker Productivity Score
abstract: Across industries and incomes, more employees are being tracked, recorded and ranked. What is gained, companies say, is efficiency and accountability. What is lost?

title: I Was Skeptical of Baby Gear. Then I Became a Dad.
abstract: Fears of pointless consumerism were no match for the joy and relief our gear provided.

title: How Frustration Over TikTok Has Mounted in Washington
abstract: National security concerns over the Chinese-owned viral video app remain unresolved. Lawmakers and regulators are increasingly pushing for action.

title: On Truth Social, F.B.I. Search Prompts Talk of War, Then Conspiracy
abstract: Calls for violence surged after the search of Mar-a-Lago this week, but other posters saw them as evidence of a federal plot to smear the right and confiscate guns.
byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Sheera Frenkel
